pages.raw_output:
<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 118, 379, 144]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSE™  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 171, 183, 188]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 194, 332, 210]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Multiple Choice (Core)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 246, 507, 262]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 277, 490, 322]]<|/det|>
You will need: Multiple choice answer sheet Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 338, 228, 353]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 354, 880, 522]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions.- For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D. Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Follow the instructions on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Write in soft pencil.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the multiple choice answer sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.- Do not use correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- Take the weight of \(1.0 \text{kg}\) to be \(9.8 \text{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 9.8 \text{m/s}^2\)).  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 549, 220, 564]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 565, 571, 613]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- Each correct answer will score one mark.- Any rough working should be done on this question paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 99, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 719, 91]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the oscillation of a mass suspended from a spring.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 101, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
The student pulls the mass down from its rest position P and then releases it so that it oscillates vertically.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 145, 834, 165]]<|/det|>
The student then follows the instructions listed to find the period of the oscillating mass.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 176, 480, 195]]<|/det|>
1 Count 10 complete oscillations.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 203, 556, 222]]<|/det|>
2 Divide the time on the stop-watch by 10.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 229, 772, 248]]<|/det|>
3 Start the stop-watch as the mass passes upwards through point P.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 255, 395, 273]]<|/det|>
4 Stop the stop-watch.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 284, 504, 303]]<|/det|>
What is the correct order of these instructions?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 313, 134, 331]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 313, 282, 331]]<|/det|>
1 \(\rightarrow\) 3 \(\rightarrow\) 4 \(\rightarrow\) 2

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 339, 134, 358]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 339, 282, 358]]<|/det|>
3 \(\rightarrow\) 1 \(\rightarrow\) 4 \(\rightarrow\) 2

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 367, 134, 384]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 367, 282, 384]]<|/det|>
3 \(\rightarrow\) 4 \(\rightarrow\) 1 \(\rightarrow\) 2

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 394, 133, 413]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 394, 282, 413]]<|/det|>
4 \(\rightarrow\) 3 \(\rightarrow\) 2 \(\rightarrow\) 1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 438, 96, 457]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 438, 616, 457]]<|/det|>
A student measures the average speed of a cyclist in a race.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 469, 425, 487]]<|/det|>
Which quantities must she measure?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 497, 134, 515]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 497, 922, 532]]<|/det|>
the total time taken to complete the race and the time taken for the cyclist to reach her highest speed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 540, 134, 558]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 540, 922, 574]]<|/det|>
the total time taken to complete the race and the total distance travelled by the cyclist at her highest speed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 580, 133, 598]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 580, 856, 598]]<|/det|>
the total time taken to complete the race and the total distance travelled by the cyclist

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 606, 133, 625]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 606, 866, 625]]<|/det|>
the time taken to reach her highest speed and the total distance travelled by the cyclist

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 462, 89]]<|/det|> The graph shows the motion of a sprinter. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 98, 715, 272]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 282, 556, 301]]<|/det|> She accelerates steadily from rest to \(8.0 \text{m / s}\) in 4.0 s. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 312, 688, 331]]<|/det|> How far does she travel in the last three seconds of her acceleration? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 342, 133, 359]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 342, 201, 359]]<|/det|> 9.0 m <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 342, 298, 359]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[311, 342, 336, 359]]<|/det|> 15 m <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[470, 342, 488, 359]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[495, 342, 529, 359]]<|/det|> 16 m <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 342, 635, 359]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[648, 342, 695, 359]]<|/det|> 24 m <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 386, 97, 403]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 386, 437, 403]]<|/det|> A person steps onto a bathroom scale. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 416, 541, 435]]<|/det|> The bathroom scale records both mass and weight. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 447, 569, 465]]<|/det|> Which row shows the readings on the bathroom scale? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 476, 390, 604]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 330, 920, 364]]<|/det|>
A uniform wooden ruler is pivoted at its centre. A load of 2.0 N is suspended from each end of the ruler.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[228, 373, 764, 477]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 491, 510, 510]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 522, 280, 540]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 551, 138, 568]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 551, 198, 568]]<|/det|>
2.0N

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 579, 131, 596]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 579, 334, 596]]<|/det|>
the weight of the ruler

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 604, 141, 622]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 604, 198, 622]]<|/det|>
4.0N

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 631, 133, 648]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 631, 420, 648]]<|/det|>
4.0N plus the weight of the ruler

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 462, 107, 481]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 462, 719, 481]]<|/det|> The table shows different types of wave in the electromagnetic spectrum. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 490, 850, 537]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 549, 531, 567]]<|/det|> Where do all the waves travel at the same speed? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 578, 138, 596]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 578, 255, 596]]<|/det|> in a vacuum <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 604, 138, 622]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 604, 247, 622]]<|/det|> in diamond <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 631, 138, 648]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 631, 220, 648]]<|/det|> in glass <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 657, 138, 675]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 657, 220, 675]]<|/det|> in water <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 700, 107, 719]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 700, 890, 719]]<|/det|> Which statement about a sound that can be heard by a person with normal hearing is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 728, 133, 747]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 728, 789, 747]]<|/det|> The sound is a longitudinal wave with a frequency between \(2.0 \text{ Hz}\) and \(20 \text{ Hz}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 755, 133, 774]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 755, 816, 774]]<|/det|> The sound is a longitudinal wave with a frequency between \(20 \text{ Hz}\) and \(20 000 \text{ Hz}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 782, 133, 801]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 782, 801, 801]]<|/det|> The sound is a transverse wave with a frequency between \(2.0 \text{ Hz}\) and \(2000 \text{ Hz}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 808, 133, 827]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 808, 796, 827]]<|/det|> The sound is a transverse wave with a frequency between \(2.0 \text{ Hz}\) and \(20 \text{ MHz}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 107, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 685, 89]]<|/det|> A hard magnetic material can be used to make a permanent magnet. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 670, 119]]<|/det|> A soft magnetic material can be used to make a temporary magnet. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 132, 755, 149]]<|/det|> Which row shows whether iron and steel are hard or soft magnetic materials? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 161, 351, 289]]<|/det|>
ironsteel

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 317, 107, 335]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 317, 551, 335]]<|/det|> A battery is connected to an ammeter and a resistor. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[391, 345, 599, 453]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 463, 376, 481]]<|/det|> The ammeter reading is 0.20 A. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 494, 630, 511]]<|/det|> An electrical insulator is connected in parallel with the resistor. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 524, 368, 542]]<|/det|> What is the ammeter reading? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 553, 131, 570]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 553, 181, 570]]<|/det|> 0A <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 580, 131, 597]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 580, 348, 597]]<|/det|> between 0A and 0.20A <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 606, 131, 624]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 606, 208, 624]]<|/det|> 0.20A <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 633, 131, 651]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 633, 312, 650]]<|/det|> greater than 0.20A <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 675, 107, 693]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 675, 603, 693]]<|/det|> Which unit is used to measure electromotive force (e.m.f.)? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 704, 134, 722]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 704, 220, 722]]<|/det|> ampere <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 732, 133, 749]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 732, 195, 749]]<|/det|> joule <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 758, 133, 776]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 758, 188, 776]]<|/det|> volt <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 785, 138, 802]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 785, 191, 802]]<|/det|> watt <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 828, 107, 846]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 828, 821, 846]]<|/det|> Which equation is correct for resistance \(R\), potential difference (p.d.) \(V\) and current \(I\)? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 857, 133, 876]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 856, 210, 883]]<|/det|> \(R = \frac{V}{I}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 856, 300, 875]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[319, 856, 400, 875]]<|/det|> \(R = V + I\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 856, 468, 875]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 856, 544, 883]]<|/det|> \(R = \frac{I}{V}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 857, 636, 876]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[650, 857, 734, 875]]<|/det|> \(R = V\times I\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>28</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 621, 90]]<|/det|>
In the diagram, rod R is suspended from an insulating thread.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[324, 97, 667, 240]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 252, 873, 272]]<|/det|>
When the positively charged rod Q is brought close to rod R, rod R moves away from rod Q.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 282, 564, 301]]<|/det|>
Which conclusion can be made from this observation?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 312, 134, 330]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 312, 744, 331]]<|/det|>
Rod R is charged, but it is not possible to identify the sign of the charge.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 338, 134, 356]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 338, 437, 356]]<|/det|>
Rod R must be positively charged.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 364, 134, 382]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 364, 445, 382]]<|/det|>
Rod R must be negatively charged.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 390, 133, 408]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 390, 324, 408]]<|/det|>
Rod R is uncharged.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 434, 104, 453]]<|/det|>
<label>29</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 434, 646, 453]]<|/det|>
In which heating system circuit would thermistors **not** be useful?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 463, 131, 481]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 463, 551, 481]]<|/det|>
to keep different rooms at different temperatures

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 489, 131, 508]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 489, 507, 508]]<|/det|>
to turn an alarm on if the system overheats

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 516, 131, 534]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 516, 601, 534]]<|/det|>
to turn a heating system off at a particular temperature

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 542, 133, 560]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 542, 594, 560]]<|/det|>
to turn a heating system on when a sound is detected

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 585, 106, 604]]<|/det|>
<label>30</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 585, 348, 604]]<|/det|>
Which statement is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 615, 133, 632]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 615, 732, 632]]<|/det|>
A fuse is included in a circuit to prevent the current becoming too high.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 641, 133, 660]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 641, 616, 660]]<|/det|>
A fuse should be connected to the neutral wire in a plug.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 667, 133, 685]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 667, 571, 685]]<|/det|>
An electric circuit will only work if it includes a fuse.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 693, 133, 711]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 693, 581, 711]]<|/det|>
An earth wire is needed to prevent the fuse blowing.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 106, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>31</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 767, 92]]<|/det|>
Which graph of current \(I\) against time \(t\) represents an alternating current (a.c.)?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 101, 892, 380]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 402, 107, 421]]<|/det|>
<label>32</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 402, 771, 422]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a wire in the magnetic field between two poles of a magnet.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[324, 432, 665, 570]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 584, 920, 619]]<|/det|>
The current in the wire repeatedly changes between a constant value in one direction and a constant value in the opposite direction, as shown in the graph.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[287, 628, 702, 757]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 769, 369, 787]]<|/det|>
What is the effect on the wire?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 797, 134, 816]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 797, 824, 816]]<|/det|>
The force on the wire alternates between one direction and the opposite direction.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 824, 133, 842]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 824, 598, 842]]<|/det|>
The force on the wire is constant in size and direction.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 851, 133, 870]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 851, 546, 870]]<|/det|>
There is no force acting on the wire at any time.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 878, 133, 896]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 878, 641, 896]]<|/det|>
There is only a force on the wire when the current reverses.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|> A transformer has \(N_{\mathrm{p}}\) turns on its primary coil and \(N_{\mathrm{s}}\) turns on its secondary coil. The voltage across the primary coil is \(V_{\mathrm{p}}\) and the voltage across the secondary coil is \(V_{\mathrm{s}}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 116, 571, 135]]<|/det|> What is the relationship between these four quantities? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 145, 134, 164]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 145, 295, 163]]<|/det|> \(V_{\mathrm{p}}\times V_{\mathrm{s}} = N_{\mathrm{p}}\times N_{\mathrm{s}}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 175, 134, 195]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 170, 228, 195]]<|/det|> \(\frac{V_{\mathrm{p}}}{V_{\mathrm{s}}} = \frac{N_{\mathrm{p}}}{N_{\mathrm{s}}}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 222, 134, 241]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 216, 228, 255]]<|/det|> \(\frac{V_{\mathrm{p}}}{V_{\mathrm{s}}} = \frac{N_{\mathrm{s}}}{N_{\mathrm{p}}}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 272, 134, 291]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 266, 260, 301]]<|/det|> \(\frac{V_{\mathrm{p}}}{V_{\mathrm{s}}} = N_{\mathrm{p}}\times N_{\mathrm{s}}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 330, 106, 349]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 330, 841, 349]]<|/det|> The diagrams represent the protons, neutrons and electrons in different atoms and ions. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 361, 515, 380]]<|/det|> Which diagram shows a negatively charged ion? <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[222, 388, 771, 675]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 699, 106, 717]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 699, 646, 717]]<|/det|> Which row correctly describes an example of radioactive decay? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 728, 662, 874]]<|/det|>
original nucleusemissionchange or no change of element
Astableγchange of element
Bunstableαchange of element
Cunstableαno change of element
Dunstableβno change of element

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 843, 89]]<|/det|> A detector is used to monitor the emissions from a radioactive source over several days. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 655, 120]]<|/det|> The table shows the count rate from the source at different times. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[368, 131, 630, 327]]<|/det|>
time/dayscount rate counts/s
0250
1215
2180
3148
4120
5100
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 339, 400, 357]]<|/det|> What is the half-life of the source? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 367, 134, 384]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 367, 339, 384]]<|/det|> between 1 and 2 days <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 393, 134, 411]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 393, 339, 411]]<|/det|> between 2 and 3 days <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 420, 134, 439]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 420, 339, 437]]<|/det|> between 3 and 4 days <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 446, 134, 465]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 446, 339, 463]]<|/det|> between 4 and 5 days <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 490, 106, 508]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 490, 920, 524]]<|/det|> What is the most effective precaution to reduce the risk when handling, storing or using a radioactive source that emits \(\gamma\) -rays? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 535, 134, 553]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 535, 526, 553]]<|/det|> Handle the source for the least possible time. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 562, 131, 580]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 562, 608, 580]]<|/det|> Have a fire extinguisher nearby when using the source. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 588, 131, 606]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 588, 470, 606]]<|/det|> Store the source at a low temperature. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 615, 131, 632]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 615, 603, 632]]<|/det|> Wear plastic safety goggles when handling the source. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 658, 106, 676]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 658, 635, 676]]<|/det|> Approximately how long does the Moon take to orbit the Earth? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 686, 134, 704]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 686, 201, 704]]<|/det|> 1 day <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 712, 134, 730]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 712, 212, 730]]<|/det|> 7 days <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 739, 134, 757]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 739, 222, 757]]<|/det|> 28 days <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 765, 134, 782]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 765, 232, 782]]<|/det|> 365 days

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 107, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>39</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 72, 714, 89]]<|/det|>
The Sun transfers energy to the Earth through electromagnetic radiation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 102, 908, 120]]<|/det|>
What are two of the parts of the electromagnetic spectrum to which most of the energy belongs?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 131, 134, 149]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 131, 351, 149]]<|/det|>
gamma rays and X-rays

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 158, 134, 175]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 156, 428, 175]]<|/det|>
infrared radiation and visible light

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 184, 133, 201]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 183, 388, 201]]<|/det|>
microwaves and visible light

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 210, 133, 227]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 210, 393, 227]]<|/det|>
radio waves and microwaves

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 254, 107, 272]]<|/det|>
<label>40</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 253, 583, 272]]<|/det|>
What provides evidence that the Universe is expanding?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 282, 133, 300]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 282, 569, 300]]<|/det|>
Stars in galaxies outside the Milky Way are all red.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 310, 133, 327]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 308, 616, 327]]<|/det|>
The Andromeda galaxy is moving toward the Milky Way.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 336, 133, 353]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 335, 638, 352]]<|/det|>
Light from distant galaxies is shifted to longer wavelengths.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 361, 133, 378]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 361, 447, 378]]<|/det|>
The Universe is 14 billion years old.
